description: Individual geopolitical analysis cards - one card per significant event with full framework

cards.headline: What are Iranians saying about the threat of war?
cards.signal: Military action tests resolve and signals willingness to use force; demonstrates shift in conflict dynamics or strategic risk tolerance.
cards.mechanism: Capital-with-conditions: Loans/investments carry interest payments, collateral claims, policy conditions. Creditor gains leverage over debtor's domestic choices.
cards.winners_losers: WINNERS: Military-industrial complex gains weapons sales and contracts; dominant military power gains territorial/geopolitical gains. LOSERS: Civilian populations face casualties and displacement; defeated state loses sovereignty. CHANNEL: Armed violence and coercion.
cards.hidden_cost_gain: Debt obligations constrain future government spending permanently. Interest payments enrich foreign creditors indefinitely. Privatization demands strip state assets. Becomes self-reinforcing.
cards.second_order_effects: Aggressor emboldened by success. Victim's weakness attracts further predation. Regional states forced to choose sides. Escalation spirals as deterrence fails.
cards.time_horizon: Structural (repayment obligations extend 20-30 years; create permanent leverage)
cards.effect_on_future_options: CONSTRAINS: Repayment obligations constrain future budgets. Creditors gain veto over domestic policy. Structural adjustment demands.
cards.reversibility: Costly (obligations cannot be erased; default damages credit for decades)
cards.confidence_level: Medium (depends on commodity prices, sustainability, political stability)
cards.one_line_take: Military action demonstrates willingness to use force; precedent invites further aggression; victim's weakness becomes target.

cards.headline: NBA roundup: Lakers stop 76ers despite Luka Doncic’s injury exit
cards.signal: Military action tests resolve and signals willingness to use force; demonstrates shift in conflict dynamics or strategic risk tolerance.
cards.mechanism: Military coercion: Threat or use of force creates vulnerability; victim must concede to demands or face escalation.
cards.winners_losers: WINNERS: Military-industrial complex gains weapons sales and contracts; dominant military power gains territorial/geopolitical gains. LOSERS: Civilian populations face casualties and displacement; defeated state loses sovereignty. CHANNEL: Armed violence and coercion.
cards.hidden_cost_gain: Long-term irreversible impacts obscured by short-term visible gains. What appears reversible becomes structural.
cards.second_order_effects: Aggressor emboldened by success. Victim's weakness attracts further predation. Regional states forced to choose sides. Escalation spirals as deterrence fails.
cards.effect_on_future_options: CONSTRAINS: Establishes new status quo politically hard to reverse.
cards.one_line_take: Military action demonstrates willingness to use force; precedent invites further aggression; victim's weakness becomes target.

cards.headline: Gunmen kill more than 160 people in attacks on two west Nigeria villages

cards.headline: Ugandan opposition leader still in hiding as feud with president’s son escalates
cards.signal: Personal interests of political elites are being negotiated as national interests, collapsing the boundary between state and private profit.
cards.mechanism: Equipment dependency: Once armed with specific weapons, buyer must maintain supplier relationship for spare parts, training, upgrades. Supply becomes geopolitical lever.
cards.winners_losers: WINNERS: US/supplier defense contractors gain market access and long-term equipment sales; geopolitical influence expands. LOSERS: Allied states lose autonomy in military procurement and doctrine; doctrine convergence eliminates strategic options. CHANNEL: Equipment dependency and interoperability lock-in.
cards.hidden_cost_gain: Equipment dependency creates permanent supplier leverage. Spare parts can be weaponized. Doctrine convergence eliminates future strategic options. Military subordination becomes normal.
cards.second_order_effects: Supplier becomes confident asserting demands. Doctrine convergence reduces strategic autonomy. Supplier expands military presence. Conflicts become more likely as military capabilities align with power politics.
cards.time_horizon: Strategic (geopolitical repositioning plays out over years; embedded through doctrine)
cards.effect_on_future_options: LOCKS IN: Equipment, doctrine, training, interoperability tied to supplier. Cannot diversify without retraining entire military.
cards.reversibility: Costly (requires rearming with alternatives, doctrine retraining, geopolitical realignment)
cards.confidence_level: High (personal interest motive clear; outcomes predictable)
cards.one_line_take: Personal wealth accumulation dressed as state interest; incentive structure permanently corrupted; elites now entrenched.

cards.headline: Death of Nigerian singer after snakebite highlights crisis of ‘preventable’ fatalities
cards.signal: This event redistributes power, resources, or constraints between key actors in ways that reshape future possibilities.
cards.mechanism: Capital-with-conditions: Loans/investments carry interest payments, collateral claims, policy conditions. Creditor gains leverage over debtor's domestic choices.
cards.winners_losers: WINNERS: Concentrated benefits (profits, market access, power). LOSERS: Distributed costs (consumers, taxpayers, excluded groups) harder to organize politically.
cards.hidden_cost_gain: Debt obligations constrain future government spending permanently. Interest payments enrich foreign creditors indefinitely. Privatization demands strip state assets. Becomes self-reinforcing.
cards.second_order_effects: Precedent makes similar arrangements more likely with other states. Escalation becomes default dynamic. Power concentrates.
cards.time_horizon: Structural (repayment obligations extend 20-30 years; create permanent leverage)
cards.effect_on_future_options: CONSTRAINS: Repayment obligations constrain future budgets. Creditors gain veto over domestic policy. Structural adjustment demands.
cards.reversibility: Costly (obligations cannot be erased; default damages credit for decades)
cards.confidence_level: Medium (depends on commodity prices, sustainability, political stability)
cards.one_line_take: Event accelerates power concentration; weaker actors lose options; precedent makes worse outcomes more likely.

cards.headline: Watch: Trump calls for new nuclear treaty as New START expires
cards.signal: This event redistributes power, resources, or constraints between key actors in ways that reshape future possibilities.
cards.mechanism: Equipment dependency: Once armed with specific weapons, buyer must maintain supplier relationship for spare parts, training, upgrades. Supply becomes geopolitical lever.
cards.winners_losers: WINNERS: US/supplier defense contractors gain market access and long-term equipment sales; geopolitical influence expands. LOSERS: Allied states lose autonomy in military procurement and doctrine; doctrine convergence eliminates strategic options. CHANNEL: Equipment dependency and interoperability lock-in.
cards.hidden_cost_gain: Equipment dependency creates permanent supplier leverage. Spare parts can be weaponized. Doctrine convergence eliminates future strategic options. Military subordination becomes normal.
cards.second_order_effects: Supplier becomes confident asserting demands. Doctrine convergence reduces strategic autonomy. Supplier expands military presence. Conflicts become more likely as military capabilities align with power politics.
cards.time_horizon: Structural (locks in constraints for decades; reversibility is political suicide)
cards.effect_on_future_options: LOCKS IN: Equipment, doctrine, training, interoperability tied to supplier. Cannot diversify without retraining entire military.
cards.reversibility: Near-irreversible (requires international negotiation; withdrawal triggers sanctions)
cards.confidence_level: High (legal constraints explicit; reversibility requires negotiation)
cards.one_line_take: Locked in structural constraints that cannot be reversed without international confrontation and domestic upheaval.
